answers.text: International Crops Research Institute for the Semi-Arid Tropics

qas.question: What types of efforts to aid in health problems have been made?
The local communities have accepted equinut because it is similar to what native recipe?
ICRISTAT had success in teaching women how to make what product of nutritional value?
What ingredients are in both the traditional and nutritional version of this dish?

answers.text: peanut paste, honey and millet or rice flour

qas.question: Little effort has been made to improve what?
What are men encouraged to cook?
What is boosted by producing a product men can sell?
What is not accepted by the local community?

context: Efforts have been made to <a1_0>improve <b5_0>nutrition<b5_0/><a1_0/>, and reduce associated health problems, by encouraging women to make <b6_0><b8_0>nutritious versions of local recipes<b8_0/><b6_0/>. For example, the <a0_0>International Crops Research Institute for the Semi-Arid Tropics<a0_0/> (ICRISAT) and the Aga Khan Foundation, trained women's groups to make <a3_0>equinut<a3_0/>, a healthy and nutritional version of the traditional <a2_0>recipe di-dèguè<a2_0/> (comprising <a4_0>peanut paste, honey and millet or rice flour<a4_0/>). The aim was to boost <b7_0>nutrition and livelihoods<b7_0/> by producing a product that women could make and sell, and which would be accepted by the local community because of its local heritage.
